company.name: PLS Financial Services, Inc.
company.address: 300 N. Elizabeth Street, 4th Floor, Chicago, Illinois 60607
company.business_description: PLS Financial Services, Inc. provides management services to over 300 PLS Loan Stores and PLS Check Cashers operating in at least nine states. The company establishes policies and procedures for safe collection, handling, and disposal of sensitive consumer financial information, and offers products and services including payday loans, automobile title loans, short-term installment loans, debit cards, credit cards, and check cashing services.

case_info.legal_authority: Sections 5(a), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a), 53(b), and 56(a); Section 621(a) of the Fair Credit Reporting Act, 15 U.S.C. § 1681s(a); the Disposal Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 682; the Safeguards Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 314; and the Privacy Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 313

complaint.factual_background: PLS Financial Services and related entities operated over 300 payday loan stores and check cashing locations across multiple states, collecting sensitive consumer information including Social Security numbers, bank account information, and consumer reports. Despite written statements claiming they maintained safeguards complying with federal regulations, the defendants failed to implement reasonable security measures, failed to properly dispose of sensitive documents, and failed to provide required privacy notices. As a result, intact documents containing consumers' personal information, including at least 29 consumer reports, were found in unsecured dumpsters accessible to the public.

representations_made.description: Claimed to maintain physical, electronic and procedural safeguards complying with federal regulations
representations_made.quoted_text: We maintain physical electronic and procedural safeguards that comply with federal regulations to guard your nonpublic information.

counts.title: Disposal Rule Violations
counts.representation: Defendants maintained and possessed consumer information derived from consumer reports for business purposes
counts.fact: Through acts and practices described in paragraphs 16 to 18, PLS and PLS-Illinois failed to take reasonable measures to protect against unauthorized access to or use of consumer information in connection with its disposal, including failing to implement disposal policies, train employees, and oversee proper disposal, resulting in intact documents containing personal information being found in unsecured dumpsters
counts.conclusion: PLS's and PLS-Illinois's violations of the FCRA and the Disposal Rule constitute unfair or deceptive acts or practices in violation of Section 5(a) of the FTC Act

counts.title: Safeguards Rule Violations
counts.representation: As financial institutions subject to the Safeguards Rule, PLS and PLS-Illinois were required to develop comprehensive written information security programs with reasonable administrative, technical, and physical safeguards
counts.fact: Through acts alleged in paragraph 16, PLS and PLS-Illinois failed to develop or implement reasonable administrative, technical and physical safeguards to protect the security, confidentiality and integrity of customer information, failed to identify reasonably foreseeable internal and external risks to customer information, and failed to develop, implement, or maintain a comprehensive written information security program
counts.conclusion: PLS and PLS-Illinois violated the Safeguards Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 314

counts.title: Deceptive Data Security Misrepresentation
counts.representation: Defendants represented, expressly or by implication, that they had implemented reasonable and appropriate measures to protect sensitive consumer information from unauthorized access
counts.fact: In truth and in fact, as described in paragraphs 16 to 18, Defendants did not implement reasonable and appropriate measures to protect sensitive consumer information from unauthorized access
counts.conclusion: Therefore, the representations described in paragraph 30 were false or misleading and constitute deceptive acts or practices in violation of Section 5(a) of the FTC Act

counts.title: Privacy Rule Violations - Failure to Provide Privacy Notices
counts.representation: As financial institutions subject to the Privacy Rule, PLS and PLS-Illinois were required to provide privacy notices to customers no later than when a customer relationship arises and annually for the duration of that relationship
counts.fact: As set forth in paragraph 19, at various times from at least March 2009 through October 2010, PLS and PLS-Illinois failed to ensure that their customers were provided with a copy of its privacy policy, with files in many PLS Loan Stores having unsigned, outdated or missing privacy notices
counts.conclusion: PLS and PLS-Illinois violated the Privacy Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 313

definitions.PLS: PLS Financial Services, Inc., and its successors and assigns. PLS is part of a common enterprise that includes entities that hold themselves out as PLS Loan Stores and PLS Check Cashers.
definitions.Group: PLS Group, Inc., and its successors and assigns. Group is part of a common enterprise that includes entities that hold themselves out as PLS Loan Stores and PLS Check Cashers.
definitions.PLS-Illinois: The Payday Loan Store of Illinois, Inc., and its successors and assigns. PLS-Illinois is part of a common enterprise that includes entities that hold themselves out as PLS Loan Stores and PLS Check Cashers.
definitions.Defendants: PLS, Group, and PLS-Illinois, individually, collectively, or in any combination.
definitions.Covered Entity: any business entity that Group controls, directly or indirectly, which collects, handles, or stores personal information. Because PLS-Illinois is a Covered Entity, 'Non-Defendant Covered Entity' means any Covered Entity other than PLS-Illinois.
definitions.person, consumer, and consumer report: as defined in Sections 603(b), (c), and (d), respectively, of the FCRA, 15 U.S.C. §§ 1681a(b), 1681a(c), and 1681a(d).
definitions.Personal information: individually identifiable information from or about an individual consumer including but not limited to: (a) a first and last name; (b) a home or other physical address, including street name and name of city or town; (c) an email address or other online contact information, such as an instant messaging user identifier or a screen name; (d) a telephone number; (e) a Social Security number; (f) a driver's license or other state-issued identification number; (g) a financial institution account number; (h) credit or debit card information; (i) a persistent identifier, such as a customer number held in a 'cookie,' a static Internet Protocol ('IP') address, or processor serial number; or (j) any information that is combined with any of (a) through (i) above.
definitions.Disposal Rule: the rule regarding the Disposal of Consumer Report Information and Records, 16 C.F.R. § 682.1 et seq.
definitions.Consumer information: any record about an individual, whether in paper, electronic, or other form, that is a consumer report or is derived from a consumer report. Consumer information also means a compilation of such records. Consumer information does not include information that does not identify individuals, such as aggregate information or blind data.
definitions.Safeguards Rule: the rule regarding the Standards for Safeguarding Customer Information, 16 C.F.R. § 314.1 et seq.
definitions.Commerce: as defined in Section 4 of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 44.
definitions.Privacy Rule: the rule regarding the Privacy of Consumer Financial Information, 16 C.F.R. § 313.1 et seq.

provisions.title: Civil Penalty
provisions.summary: Judgment of $101,500 is entered against PLS and PLS-Illinois jointly and severally, to be paid to the U.S. Treasury within seven days of entry of the Order.

requirements.description: Pay civil penalty of $101,500 to the Treasurer of the United States
requirements.quoted_text: Judgment in the amount of $ 101,500.00 (One hundred one thousand five hundred dollars) is entered against PLS and PLS-Illinois, jointly and severally, as a civil penalty, pursuant to Section 621(a) of the FCRA, 15 U.S.C. § 1681s(a), as adjusted by 16 C.F.R. § 1.98(m).

requirements.description: Transfer payment from escrow to Treasurer of the United States
requirements.quoted_text: Within seven (7) days of entry of this Order, PLS's and PLS-Illinois's attorneys shall transfer the sum in the form of a wire transfer or certified or cashier's check made payable to the Treasurer of the United States.

provisions.title: Prohibited Business Activities
provisions.summary: Defendants are permanently enjoined from misrepresenting data security practices and from violating the FCRA Disposal Rule, GLB Safeguards Rule, and GLB Privacy Rule.

requirements.description: Must not misrepresent the extent to which they maintain and protect the security, privacy, confidentiality, or integrity of personal information
requirements.quoted_text: Defendants and their agents, servants, and employees and all persons in active concert or participation with any one or more of them, including all Covered Entities, whether acting directly or through any sole proprietorship, partnership, limited liability company, corporation, subsidiary, branch, division, or other entity who receive actual notice of this Order by personal service or otherwise, are hereby permanently restrained and enjoined, in connection with their advertising, marketing, promotion, or offering of any service or product in or affecting commerce, from making any representation, in any manner, expressly or by implication, about the extent to which Defendants maintain and protect the security, privacy, confidentiality, or integrity of any personal information collected from or about consumers, unless the representation is true, and non-misleading.

requirements.description: Must not violate Section 628 of the FCRA or the Disposal Rule by failing to properly dispose of consumer information
requirements.quoted_text: Violating Section 628 of the FCRA or the Disposal Rule, including but not limited to, by maintaining or otherwise possessing consumer information for a business purpose and failing to properly dispose of such information by taking reasonable measures to protect against unauthorized access to or use of the information in connection with its disposal.

requirements.description: Must not violate the GLB Act or Safeguards Rule by failing to develop, implement, or maintain a comprehensive written information security program
requirements.quoted_text: Violating Title V, Subtitle A of the GLB Act or the Safeguards Rule, including but not limited to, by failing to develop, implement, or maintain a comprehensive written information security program containing reasonable administrative, technical and physical safeguards, including safeguards used to access, collect, distribute, process, protect, store, use, transmit, dispose of, or otherwise handle customer information;

requirements.description: Must not violate the GLB Act or Privacy Rule by failing to provide privacy notices to consumers
requirements.quoted_text: Violating Title V, Subtitle A of the GLB Act or the Privacy Rule, including but not limited to, by failing to provide consumers, no later than when a customer relationship arises and annually for the duration of that relationship, a clear and conspicuous notice that accurately reflects its privacy policies and practices, including its security policies and practices.

provisions.title: Required Information Security Program
provisions.summary: Defendants must establish and maintain a comprehensive information security program with administrative, technical, and physical safeguards to protect personal information.

requirements.description: Establish and implement a comprehensive information security program no later than the date of entry of the Order
requirements.quoted_text: Defendants, for themselves and all Non-Defendant Covered Entities, shall, no later than the date of entry of this Order, establish and implement, and thereafter maintain, a comprehensive information security program that is designed to protect the security, confidentiality, and integrity of personal information collected from or about consumers. Such program, the content and implementation of which must be fully documented in writing, shall contain administrative, technical, and physical safeguards appropriate to Defendants' and the Covered Entity's size and complexity, the nature and scope of Defendants' and the Covered Entity's activities, and the sensitivity of the personal information collected from or about consumers

requirements.description: Designate employee(s) to coordinate and be accountable for the information security program
requirements.quoted_text: The designation of an employee or employees to coordinate and be accountable for the information security program;

requirements.description: Identify material internal and external risks to security, confidentiality and integrity of personal information and assess sufficiency of safeguards
requirements.quoted_text: The identification of material internal and external risks to the security, confidentiality and integrity of personal information that could result in the unauthorized disclosure, misuse, loss, alteration, destruction, or other compromise of such information, and the assessment of the sufficiency of any safeguards in place to control the risks. At a minimum, this risk assessment should include consideration of the risks in each relevant area of operations, including but not limited to (1) employee training and management; (2) information systems, including network and software design, information processing, storage, transmission, and disposal; and (3) prevention, detection, and response to attacks, intrusions, or other system failures;

requirements.description: Design and implement reasonable safeguards to control identified risks and regularly test and monitor their effectiveness
requirements.quoted_text: The design and implementation of reasonable safeguards to control the risks identified through risk assessment, and regular testing and monitoring of the effectiveness of the safeguards' key controls, systems, and procedures;

requirements.description: Take reasonable steps to select and retain service providers capable of safeguarding personal information and require them by contract to implement appropriate safeguards
requirements.quoted_text: The development and use of reasonable steps to select and retain service providers capable of appropriately safeguarding personal information received from Defendants and the Covered Entity, and requiring service providers by contract to implement and maintain appropriate safeguards;

requirements.description: Evaluate and adjust the information security program based on testing results, material changes to operations, or other circumstances
requirements.quoted_text: The evaluation and adjustment of the information security program in light of the results of the testing and monitoring required by paragraph C of this Section III, any material changes to operations or business arrangements, or any other circumstances that Defendants or the Covered Entity knows or has reason toknow may have a material impact on the effectiveness of the information security program.

provisions.title: Assessment Requirements
provisions.summary: Defendants must obtain initial and biennial third-party security assessments for 20 years, with the initial assessment covering the first 180 days and subsequent assessments every two years.

requirements.description: Obtain initial and biennial assessments from a qualified, independent third-party professional
requirements.quoted_text: In connection with their compliance with Sections II(B)(1), II(B)(2) and III of this Order, Defendants shall obtain initial and biennial assessments and reports (Assessments) for Defendants and any Non-Defendant Covered Entity from a qualified, objective, independent third-party professional who uses procedures and standards generally accepted in the profession.

requirements.description: Initial assessment must cover the first 180 days after service of the Order
requirements.quoted_text: The reporting period for the Assessments shall cover: (1) the first one hundred and eighty (180) days after service of the Order for the initial Assessment; and (2) each two (2) year period thereafter for twenty (20) years after service of the Order for the biennial Assessments.

requirements.description: Each assessment must be prepared and completed within 60 days after the end of the reporting period
requirements.quoted_text: Each Assessment shall be prepared and completed within sixty (60) days after the end of the reporting period to which the Assessment applies.

requirements.description: Provide initial assessment to the Associate Director of Enforcement within 10 days after preparation
requirements.quoted_text: Defendants and any Covered Entity shall provide the initial Assessment to the Associate Director of Enforcement, Federal Trade Commission, 600 Pennsylvania Avenue, NW, Washington, DC 20580, within ten (10) days after the Assessment has been prepared.

requirements.description: Retain all subsequent biennial assessments and provide them to the FTC within 10 days of request
requirements.quoted_text: All subsequent biennial Assessments shall be retained by Defendants until the Order is terminated and provided to the Associate Director of Enforcement within ten (10) days of request.

provisions.title: Order Acknowledgments
provisions.summary: Defendants must submit acknowledgments of receipt of the Order and distribute the Order to personnel and obtain signed acknowledgments from them.

requirements.description: Submit acknowledgment of receipt of Order to the Commission
requirements.quoted_text: Each Defendant, within 7 days of entry of this Order, must submit to the Commission an acknowledgment of receipt of this Order sworn under penalty of perjury.

requirements.description: Deliver a copy of the Order to all principals, officers, directors, managers, employees, agents, and representatives for 20 years
requirements.quoted_text: For 20 years after entry of this Order, each Defendant must deliver a copy of this Order to: (1) all principals, officers, directors, and managers; (2) all employees, agents, and representatives who participate in conduct related to the subject matter of this Order; and (3) any business entity resulting from any change in structure as set forth in the Section titled Compliance Reporting. Delivery must occur within 7 days of entry of this Order for current personnel. To all others, delivery must occur before they assume their responsibilities.

requirements.description: Obtain signed and dated acknowledgments of receipt from individuals and entities to which the Order was delivered
requirements.quoted_text: From each individual or entity to which Defendants delivered a copy of this Order, Defendants must obtain, within 30 days, a signed and dated acknowledgment of receipt of this Order.

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: Defendants must submit compliance reports and notices to the Commission, including an initial compliance report one year after entry of the Order and ongoing notices for 20 years regarding changes in structure or contact information.

requirements.description: Submit initial compliance report one year after entry of the Order
requirements.quoted_text: One year after entry of this Order, each Defendant must submit a compliance report, sworn under penalty of perjury. Each Defendant must: (a) designate at least one telephone number and an email, physical, and postal address as points of contact, which representatives of the Commission and Plaintiff may use to communicate with Defendant; (b) identify all of Defendant's businesses by all of their names, telephone numbers, and physical, postal, email, and Internet addresses; (c) describe the activities of each business, including the products and services offered, and the means of advertising, marketing, and sales, and the involvement of any other Defendant; (d) describe in detail whether and how that Defendant is in compliance with each Section of this Order; and (e) provide a copy of each Order Acknowledgment obtained pursuant to this Order, unless previously submitted to the Commission;

requirements.description: Submit compliance notice within 14 days of any change in designated point of contact or structure
requirements.quoted_text: For 20 years following entry of this Order, each Defendant must submit a compliance notice, sworn under penalty of perjury, within 14 days of any change in (a) any designated point of contact; or (b) the structure of any Defendant or any entity that Defendant has any ownership interest in or directly or indirectly controls that may affect compliance obligations arising under this Order, including: creation, merger, sale, or dissolution of the entity or any subsidiary, parent, or affiliate that engages in any acts or practices subject to this Order.

requirements.description: Submit notice of bankruptcy filing within 14 days
requirements.quoted_text: Each Defendant must submit to the Commission notice of the filing of any bankruptcy petition, insolvency proceeding, or any similar proceeding by or against such Defendant within 14 days of its filing.

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Defendants must create and retain records for 20 years, including accounting records, personnel records, complaints, compliance records, and marketing materials, with each record retained for 5 years.

requirements.description: Create records for 20 years after entry of the Order and retain each record for 5 years
requirements.quoted_text: Defendants must create certain records for 20 years after entry of the Order, and retain each such record for 5 years. Specifically, Defendants must maintain the following records: A. Accounting records showing the revenues from all goods and services sold, all costs incurred in generating those revenues, and the resulting net profit or loss; B. Personnel records showing, for each person providing services, whether as an employee or otherwise, that person's: name, addresses, and telephone numbers; job title or position; dates of service; and, if applicable, the reason for termination; C. Written complaints and refund requests, whether received directly or indirectly, such as through a third party, and any response; D. All records necessary to demonstrate full compliance with each provision of this Order, including all submissions to the Commission; and E. A copy of each advertisement or other marketing material.

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: The FTC and Plaintiff may monitor Defendants' compliance through requests for reports, depositions, document production, interviews, and other investigative means including posing as consumers.

requirements.description: Submit additional compliance reports or requested information within 14 days of written request from FTC or Plaintiff
requirements.quoted_text: Within 14 days of receipt of a written request from a representative of the Commission or Plaintiff, each Defendant must: submit additional compliance reports or other requested information, which must be sworn under penalty of perjury; appear for depositions; and produce documents for inspection and copying.

requirements.description: Permit FTC and Plaintiff to communicate directly with Defendants and interview employees or affiliated persons
requirements.quoted_text: For matters concerning this Order, the Commission and Plaintiff are authorized to communicate directly with each Defendant. Defendants must permit representatives of the Commission and Plaintiff to interview any employee or other person affiliated with any Defendant who has agreed to such an interview. The person interviewed may have counsel present.

requirements.description: Allow FTC and Plaintiff to use lawful investigative means including posing as consumers
requirements.quoted_text: The Commission and Plaintiff may use all other lawful means, including posing, through their representatives, as consumers, suppliers, or other individuals or entities, to Defendants or any individual or entity affiliated with Defendants, without the necessity of identification or prior notice.

provisions.title: Retention of Jurisdiction
provisions.summary: The Court retains jurisdiction of the matter for purposes of construction, modification, and enforcement of the Order.

requirements.description: Court retains jurisdiction for construction, modification, and enforcement
requirements.quoted_text: IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that this Court retains jurisdiction of this matter for purposes of construction, modification, and enforcement of this Order.

duration.termination_text: For 20 years after entry of this Order, each Defendant must deliver a copy of this Order to: (1) all principals, officers, directors, and managers; (2) all employees, agents, and representatives who participate in conduct related to the subject matter of this Order; and (3) any business entity resulting from any change in structure as set forth in the Section titled Compliance Reporting.
